critique: This document establishes an emergency board to investigate disputes between railroads and their employees. It aims to prevent interruption of interstate commerce. There's no direct indication of ideological tilt, immigration stance, or social inclusion. It could be argued that establishing the board expands executive power slightly, but it's primarily an action to maintain the status quo and prevent disruption. It doesn't significantly impact federalism or national security vs. civil liberties. The economic regulation aspect is moderate, as it prevents changes to existing conditions but doesn't impose new regulations.
